intro: Rhabdophyllum rubrum, commonly known as the red-stemmed fern, is a unique flowering plant native to tropical regions of Southeast Asia. It belongs to the family Araliaceae and is characterized by its striking red stems and broad, lance-shaped leaves. The plant produces small, clustered white flowers that bloom in late spring, followed by red berries containing toxic seeds. It thrives in humid, shaded environments and is often found in forest understories. Due to its ornamental value and medicinal properties, it is occasionally cultivated in botanical gardens and traditional herbal practices.
